title: OpenAI abandons plan to be controlled by for-profit board
summary:
OpenAI has been working for months to no longer be controlled by a nonprofit. It's now giving up.

In a company blog post published on Monday, nonprofit board chairman Bret Taylor said that OpenAI is abandoning its plan to become controlled by a for-profit after "hearing from civic leaders and engaging in constructive dialogue with the offices of the Attorney General of Delaware and the Attorney General of California." Both attorneys general have oversight of OpenAI and could have blocked its planned restructuring, which companies like Meta protested.

Now, OpenAI's nonprofit parent company (the same one that briefly fired CEO Sam Altman) will continue to oversee its for-profit subsidiary, which is being changed to a public benefit corporation. In a memo to OpenAI employees, CEO Sam Altman said the current for-profit structure, which capped returns investors could receive after AGI is declared, "made sense when it looked like there might be one dominant AGI effort but doesn't in a world of many great AGI companies."

## OpenAI abandons plan to be controlled by for-profit board  

OpenAI has scrapped its plan to transition to for-profit control after months of deliberation. The decision follows discussions with state attorneys general in Delaware and California, who could have blocked the restructuring. Instead, OpenAI’s nonprofit parent will continue overseeing its for-profit subsidiary, now structured as a public benefit corporation. CEO Sam Altman noted in an internal memo that the original governance model, which capped investor returns post-AGI, no longer fits a landscape with multiple AGI developers.  

### Why It Matters  

This reversal signals OpenAI’s responsiveness to regulatory and public concerns about AI governance. By retaining nonprofit oversight, the company may face stricter ethical constraints but could also avoid conflicts with policymakers and competitors like Meta. The shift to a public benefit corporation suggests a balancing act—prioritizing societal impact while operating commercially. However, the move raises questions about investor incentives and how OpenAI will navigate AGI development in a crowded field.
